items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Butte-Glenn Community College District OEI Subaward
	 
As part of the FY 14 and FY 15 budgets, the Governor proposed and the Legislature approved allocations of $16.9 and $10 million respectively for the California Community Colleges to conduct the Online Education Initiative (OEI). The California Community Colleges Chancellor’s Office (CCCCO) awarded these funds through a competitive application process to the Foothill-De Anza Community College District (FHDA) through Request for Application #13-082.  On November 12, 2013, the CCC Board of Governors confirmed this award.  Funding for the OEI Grant Year 1 became available December 1, 2013, and activities related to the project are underway.
	 
FHDA serves as the lead agency and fiscal agent for the OEI grant.  Other agencies and districts are partnering with FHDA to provide various components of the grant as detailed in the FHDA response to RFA #13-082 and approved by the California Community Colleges Chancellor’s Office.  The Butte-Glenn Community College District is the primary partner on the OEI grant and is responsible for the following components:
	 
OEI Grant Objective 4. Student Experience and Support Tools & Services
OEI Grant Objective 5. Technical Infrastructure
	 
In order to accomplish the objectives listed above, FHDA will provide the Butte-Glenn Community District with $5,142,954 from Year 1 funds and $2,981,998 from Year 2 funds.
	 
San Bernardino Community College District OEI Subaward
	 
As part of the FY 14 and FY 15 budgets, the Governor proposed and the Legislature approved allocations of $16.9 and $10 million respectively for the California Community Colleges to conduct the Online Education Initiative. The California Community Colleges Chancellor’s Office (CCCCO) awarded these funds through a competitive application process to the Foothill-De Anza Community College District through Request for Application #13-082.  On November 12, 2013, the CCC Board of Governors confirmed this award.  Funding for the OEI Grant Year 1 became available December 1, 2013, and activities related to the project are underway.
	 
FHDA serves as the lead agency and fiscal agent for the OEI grant.  Other agencies and districts are partnering with FHDA to provide various components of the grant as detailed in the FHDA response to RFA #13-082 and approved by the California Community Colleges Chancellor’s Office.  The San Bernardino Community College District is a secondary partner on the OEI grant and is responsible for the following component:
	 
The transition of EduStream video streaming services to the Southern California Telecommunications and Technology Infrastructure Program (TTIP-South), a grant to Palomar Community College District.
	 
In order to accomplish the objective listed above, FHDA will provide the San Bernardino Community District with $300,000 from Year 1 funds.
	 
Palomar Community College District OEI Subaward
	 
As part of the FY 14 and FY 15 budgets, the Governor proposed and the Legislature approved allocations of $16.9 and $10 million respectively for the California Community Colleges to conduct the Online Education Initiative. The California Community Colleges Chancellor’s Office (CCCCO) awarded these funds through a competitive application process to the Foothill-De Anza Community College District through Request for Application #13-082.  On November 12, 2013, the CCC Board of Governors confirmed this award.  Funding for the OEI Grant Year 1 became available December 1, 2013, and activities related to the project are underway.
	 
FHDA serves as the lead agency and fiscal agent for the OEI grant.  Other agencies and districts are partnering with FHDA to provide various components of the grant as detailed in the FHDA response to RFA #13-082 and approved by the California Community Colleges Chancellor’s Office.  The Southern California Telecommunications and Technology Infrastructure Program (TTIP-South), a grant to Palomar Community College District, is a secondary partner on the OEI grant and is responsible for the following component:
	 
The Online Education Initiative professional development program.  All services necessary to conduct the CCC Online Educator Training and Support Program will be provided through the @One Program currently operated by the TTIP-South grant.
	 
In order to accomplish the objective listed above, FHDA will provide the Palomar Community District with $2,500,000 from Year 1 funds.

 Joe Moreau, Vice Chancellor, Technology, x6120

Background and Analysis:
	 
The District owns surplus library furniture that will be replaced with new (see attached lists, 7 pages) during the De Anza College Library Renovation Project.  De Anza College has determined that the library furniture is not satisfactory for further use by the District.  California Education Code sections 81450 – 81452 provide that the governing board of a community college district may sell, donate, or dispose of personal property if it is unsatisfactory and no longer suitable for school use. The estimated aggregate resale value is greater $5,000.00.
	 
In an effort to best utilize District resources and expedite the process in the most efficient manner, Purchasing Services recommends that, in the best interest of the District and in the most charitable and environmentally sound way practical, the furniture be sold, donated, recycled or disposed of on-site.   Purchasing Services will attempt to sell, then donate usable furniture first to other public entitles, then to charitable organizations.   Any remaining furniture will be recycled or disposed of.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director, Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Eric Olague, Buyer, Purchasing Services

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
The international student enrollment growth over the past nine years is due primarily to our increased international student recruitment efforts and to the intensive development of formal relationships with private educational advising agencies around the world. These agents send students overseas to undertake their college and university study. Over the past six years, we employed the services of this contractor, Gregory Barattini, who helped us to significantly increase the number of relationships we maintain with agents all over China, Indonesia, the rest of Southeast Asia and Europe. This expansion was a strong factor in the past few years in the District being able to increase international student enrollment despite the very challenging economic environment. In addition, the contractor helped reduce the District’s travel expenses by representing us at many international study abroad fairs and exhibitions.
	 
This contract would extend the services of Gregory Barattini for a one-year period starting July 7, 2014. Mr. Barattini is a recognized professional expert and is the only individual known to me who provides this kind of international student recruitment representation to colleges and universities. For years, he worked as the senior vice president for marketing at several large international language school chains, recently represented Santa Monica College in a similar capacity over a four-year period, and has done an excellent job for FHDA over the past six years. His clients also include Berkeley Colleges in New York City and UCLA Extension. He fully understands what the District has to offer and how to market us abroad, and is on a first-name basis with a very large number of advising agents around the world. In addition, he is physically located in Indonesia, which allows him to travel inexpensively throughout the region and saves us considerable expenses. 
	 
The contractor will provide year-round recruitment representation in Southeast and South Asia, in Turkey and in Scandinavia. Specifically, he will:
Develop relationships for FHDA with additional new educational advising agents;
Strengthen relationships with existing agents;
Provide representation at large study abroad fairs and agent seminars; and
Provide ongoing recruitment and international marketing advice.
The contractor will provide these services to FHDA and to one or two other institutions, which will equally share in travel and related expenses.  He will not represent any other community college.
	 
The contractor will be paid $3,800.00 per month and will invoice us for the District’s share of his travel expenses, which will not exceed $50,000.00 for the academic year.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy C. Miner
Additional contact names:
George Beers

Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill College has been awarded $300,000 in funding from the California Community College's Chancellor's Office Division of Workforce and Economic Development for a one year renewal (July 1, 2014- June 30, 2015) grant for Catherine Ayers to continue her project management work as a Deputy Sector Navigator working with the Energy Efficiency industry and Utilities sector in the Bay Area. This grant is in support of the Doing What Matters for Jobs and the Economy framework to enhance collaborative regional work on curricular pathways in sectors important to regional economies. The grant project has been one of a number of Bay Area projects that has supported the creation of a network of Deputy Sector Navigators. This project continues to build upon FHDA earlier work, including the SolarTech Workforce Innovations Collaborative (SWIC) project, in the Energy sector and the successful collaborations with City College of San Francisco, Skyline College and industry partners that distinguished the first year of the grant, FY 2013-14.
	 
Catherine Ayers was named the Deputy Sector Navigator on this award as detailed in the attached Independent Contractor Agreement dated May 27, 2014, because of her experience with the energy efficiency industry and her knowledge of workforce development in the community colleges. As required by the Chancellor's Office, the Deputy Sector Navigator is an 80% to full­ time role, working with colleges, industry partners and other stakeholders for this sector in the Bay Area.
	 
The Independent Contractor Agreement was authorized by Foothill College Vice President of Workforce Development and Institutional Advancement John Mummert for $141,500 in contracted services and $4500 in expenses, for a total cost not to exceed $145,950.

The Celebrity Forum Speaker Series has been a part of Foothill College for 46 years. The series is an important community event and draws thousands of people each year to Flint Center. From its founding in 1968, the series has been completely self-supporting and has never used District or college funds for its operation, being financed solely through ticket sales. The series has always been a financial success and has contributed valuable discretionary dollars to Foothill College.

Foothill Fine Arts facilities are managed by the Fine Arts Division, while the remainder of the campus facilities rentals are managed by the Facilities Rental Coordinator under the supervision of the Facilities Director.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
In conjunction with District Board Policy 3205, De Anza College allows community groups and organizations the use of the facilities when that use does not interfere with, infringe on or impede the educational process.
	 
De Anza College celebrates the diversity of its student body and the communities from which they are drawn. items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Students involved in De Anza College's Public Policy School working in conjunction with Evolve, a San Francisco-based community organization, have advocated at recent meetings for governing board support of a resolution endorsing a change to Proposition 13. The resolution supports modification of the method by which commercial properties are assessed in order to increase funding for public schools. According to Evolve's web site, four community college districts have adopted the attached resolution supporting the effort as have a number of K-12 school districts and city councils.
	 
Proposition 13 limits the property tax rate to one percent of the assessed value of a home at the time of purchase and holds annual tax increases to no more than two percent until the property is sold. Under Proposition 13, industrial, commercial, and residential property are treated the same. When Proposition 13 passed in 1978, 40 percent of property taxes in California were paid by commercial property owners, but that percentage has been reduced to 28 percent over time, in part due to commercial property transactions in which ownership is transferred in sequential transactions among several parties to avoid triggering reassessment. Evolve estimates that an additional $6 billion per year would be available to fund public schools and services if the proposal to reassess commercial properties more often were enacted.
	 
The resolution leaves open whether the effort would be through the initiative process or via a constitutional amendment placed on the ballot by the Legislature. It is too late to begin an initiative campaign for placement on the November 2014 general election ballot, so any effort requiring signature gathering would be for 2016.

Background and Analysis:
	 
During California's economic downturn, the Board of Governors of the California Community Colleges enacted regulations to limit the repeatability of coursework in order to prioritize basic skills, career technical education, and transfer preparation over lifelong learning. The changes were made in light of severe year-over-year reductions in state funding combined with increased enrollment demands fueled in part by high unemployment rates. 
	 
The repeatability limits, change in state priorities, and workload reduction forced the colleges to make program adjustments that have negatively impacted district enrollment and reduced opportunities previously available to students in performance and skill-building courses as well as lifelong learners in the community.
	 
The attached resolution would urge the Board of Governors to adjust repeatability regulations to take into account the needs of students taking courses outside the state prioritized areas of basic skills, career technical education, and transfer preparation.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
As a result of a duly called election, on November 2, 1999, the District received authorization for the issuance of $248,000,000 of General Obligation Bonds (Measure E).  On October 4, 2005, the District issued the third series of bonds under Measure E in a principal amount of $57,904,900.25 (the “1999 Series C bonds”).  A portion of the 1999 Series C Bonds was previously refunded through the issuance of the District’s 2012 General Obligation Refunding Bonds.
	 
As a result of a duly called election, on June 6, 2006, the District received authorization for the issuance of $490,800,000 of General Obligation Bonds (Measure C).  In May 2007, the District issued the first and second series of bonds under Measure C, in the principal amounts of $149,995,250.35 (the “2006 Series A Bonds”) and $99,996,686.15 (the “2006 Series B Bonds”), respectively.  No refunding has been executed for the 2006 Series A Bonds; a portion of the 2006 Series B Bonds was previously refunded through the issuance of the District’s 2012 General Obligation Refunding Bonds.
	 
The attached analysis from Morgan Stanley indicates there is currently an opportunity for debt service savings by refinancing portions of the outstanding 1999 Series C Bonds, 2006 Series A Bonds and 2006 Series B Bonds.  The refunding opportunity is dependent on market conditions and will be evaluated for potential savings to the taxpayers at the time of the sale.  The district refinancing team composed of Business Office personnel, our underwriter, bond counsel, and our independent financial advisor will make a brief presentation explaining the terms of the agreement at the Board of Trustees meeting.
	 
Bond Resolution.  Resolution No. 2014-20 before the Board authorizes the issuance of general obligation refunding bonds (the “Bonds”) to accomplish the refinancing.  The resolution specifies the basic terms, parameters and forms of the Refunding Bonds, and approves the forms of a Purchase Contract, Escrow Agreement and Preliminary Official Statement described below.  The Refunding Bonds are only authorized to be issued as current interest bonds.  Capital appreciation bonds are not authorized.  In particular, Section 1 of the Resolution establishes the maximum aggregate principal amount of the Refunding Bonds issued ($125,000,000).  Section 4 of the Resolution states the maximum underwriting discount (1.0%) with respect to the Refunding Bonds, and authorizes the Refunding Bonds to be sold at a negotiated sale to Morgan Stanley.  All the benefits of refunding must be given to the local taxpayers; the District will not receive any money from the transaction.  
	 
Form of Purchase Contract.  Pursuant to the Purchase Contract, Morgan Stanley will agree to buy the Refunding Bonds from the District.  All the conditions of closing the transaction are set forth in this document, including the documentation to be provided at the closing by various parties.  Upon the pricing of the Refunding Bonds, the final execution copy of the Purchase Contract will be prepared following this form.
	 
Form of Preliminary Official Statement.  The Preliminary Official Statement (“POS”) is the offering document describing the Refunding Bonds, which may be distributed to prospective purchasers of the Refunding Bonds.  The POS discloses information with respect to among other things (i) the proposed uses of proceeds of the Refunding Bonds, (ii) the terms of the Refunding Bonds (interest rate, redemption terms, etc.), (iii) the bond insurance policy for the Refunding Bonds, if any, (iv) the security for repayment of the Refunding Bonds (the ad valorem tax levy), (v) information with respect to the District’s tax base (upon which such ad valorem taxes may be levied), (vi) District financial and operating data, (vii) continuing disclosure with respect to the Refunding Bonds and the District, and (viii) absence of litigation and other miscellaneous matters expected to be of interest to prospective purchasers of the Refunding Bonds.  Following the pricing of the Refunding Bonds, a final Official Statement for the Refunding Bonds will be prepared, substantially in the form of the POS.
	 
Escrow Agreement.  Pursuant to the Escrow Agreement, proceeds from the sale of the Refunding Bonds in an amount sufficient to accomplish the refunding will be deposited in an escrow fund (the “Escrow Fund”) held by U.S. Bank National Association (acting as “Escrow Agent”).  The monies in the Escrow Fund will be used by the Escrow Agent to pay each of the refunded 1999 Series C Bonds, 2006 Series A Bonds and 2006 Series B Bonds on the first available optional redemption dates therefor.  As a result of the deposit and application of funds so provided in the Escrow Agreement, the prior bonds will be completely paid off and the obligation of Santa Clara County to levy ad valorem taxes for payment of the Prior Bonds will cease.
	 
District administration is recommending approval of the resolution, which authorizes the District to exercise the refunding options if market conditions are favorable. The sale for the refunding of these bonds is currently scheduled for July 15, with a closing on August 19.
	 
Related documents included in this packet are: Morgan Stanley’s analysis of projected savings and Financing Timetable.
	 
See attached Executive Summary for more details.
	 
Vice Chancellor of Business Services, Kevin McElroy recommends that the Board:
	 
1.      Approve Resolution No. 2014-20 authorizing Issuance of 2014 General Obligation Refunding Bonds   
         (1999 Series C for Measure E and 2006 Series A and B for Measure C) (This resolution includes a  
         Form of Current Interest Bond);
	 
2.      Approve the form of the Preliminary Official Statement
	 
3.      Approve the form of the Purchase Contract and;
	 
4.      Approve the form of the Escrow Agreement.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Repairs to the District Office Building’s roof, thought to be confined to superficial dry rot to non-structural roof trim, proved to include damage to the structural framing of the building’s central space.  The resulting repair will involve replacement of primary structural roof members and repair of surrounding construction.  This work is not related to the change of occupancy of the building from District offices to ETS offices, but would have been necessary to complete the project regardless of its use.  
	 
Cody Anderson Wasney Architects developed repair plans, Alten Construction has submitted proposed costs for portions of the work, and the District and Gilbane Maas have begun negotiations on the pricing; however, final costs could not be developed to bring a change order to the Board at this meeting.
	 
In order to facilitate the Contractor’s flow of work and minimize delay impacts on the project, approval is requested to issue change directives as follows, subject to subsequent final negotiations and Board approval:  Repair of roof framing and related construction – not to exceed $200,000.
	 
Funding is planned to be transferred from Measure E Project 499, Central Services Contingency, to this project to cover the cost of the repairs.
	 
Additional Information:  The roof structure above the central open space, an addition to the building built the 1970’s, is an unusual cantilevered design that locates structural members on the outside of the building where they are exposed to the weather.  Plans to replace what was thought to be fascia trim had to be reconsidered when the heavily weathered fascia boards were discovered to be supporting the roof itself, and even portions of wall below the roof.  Bidding the framing and wall repair outside of Alten Construction’s current contract was considered but is not practical because of its integration with Alten’s scope of work inside the building.  So as not to add an additional financial burden to the current construction project with Alten Construction, the related roof membrane replacement will be bid as a separate roofing project already planned for the building.

Background and Analysis:
	 
On September 9, 2013, the Board of Trustees authorized the use of the Commonwealth contract to purchase computer tables for the ATC Building. At that time, the Associate Vice President of College Operations at De Anza College and several Deans tested the functionality of various computer tables and the group concluded that the electric table from ISE Inc. was the best fit for De Anza College. 
	 
De Anza College is in need of purchasing more electric tables from ISE Inc. and the estimated cost of the tables will exceed the current statutory bid threshold of $84,100. For purchases over the bid threshold, the District must either conduct its own bidding and award process or obtain board authorization to utilize existing contracts awarded by other public entities. This process is commonly known as “piggybacking”. The competitively bid Common Wealth of Pennsylvania contract with ISE Inc. is available and it includes the items required by the college. 
	 
It is highly unlikely that a separate bid process conducted by our District would result in more favorable prices, terms, and conditions than the prices offered on the Common Wealth of Pennsylvania contract for the same goods and services. The ISE Inc. contract establishes discounts for furniture inclusive of shipping, delivery, and a lifetime warranty. 
	 
Purchasing Services currently has one request to purchase the electric tables from ISE Inc. in the amount $88,795. This purchase will be funded by Measure C. 
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services

Donna Jones Dulin, Annette Perez

$350,000

On June 16, 2014, the apparent low bidder Stronger Building Services sent a letter to the District asking to be relieved of its bid due to a mistake in preparing its bid price.  Pursuant to Public Contract Code Section 5103, the Board of Trustees may grant relief to a bidder who claims a mistake within the 5 day written notice period provided that the mistake makes the bid materially different than what it was intended it to be, and that the mistake was made in filling out the bid and not due to error in judgment or to carelessness in inspecting the site of the work, or in reading the plans or specifications. The mistake was material and made the bid $180,000 lower than what Stronger Building Service intended it to be (see attached letter).  
	 
Therefore, Best Contracting Services, Inc., is the apparent lowest responsive and responsible bidder.  Furthermore, Best Contracting Services, Inc., and its subcontractors have signed the Appendix A, “Agreement To Be Bound,” and Appendix C, “Agreement of Contractors,” of the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building and Construction Trades Council. 
	 
Best Contracting Services, Inc. has successfully completed Bid #1120, Building 5100 Roof Replacement at Foothill College in 2008 and Bid #1637-236E, L2, L3 & L6 Roof Repairs at De Anza College in 2013. 
	 
The bid price of $594,076 submitted by Best Contracting Services, Inc. is within the construction estimate of $618,000 and it is within the overall Project #236F budget of $1,438,066.  This project is funded by Measure C.

Background and Analysis:
	 
The project includes utility repairs to rehabilitate existing sewer main located adjacent to the Lot 1 bridge structure. The work to be done includes clearing, photographing, and slip lining of existing structure. This work is required as part of a City of Los Altos special encroachment permit that was obtained to allow construction of the bridge at Parking Lot 1, a part of which is located within the City of Los Altos sewer line easement
	 
Sandis Engineers prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department. 
	 
Bid #1689-135 was legally advertised to contractors April 29, 2014, and May 6, 2014.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  A non-mandatory bid walk was held on May 13, 2014, and a total of two (2) contractors attended the walk.  Bids were publicly opened and read on June 5, 2014 in the Purchasing Services office.  Three (3) contractors submitted a bid and the bid results are summarized below:
	 
GENERAL CONTRACTORS
TOTAL BASE BID PROPOSAL AMOUNT
Nor-Cal Pipeline Services
$32,500
Dexal Construction Inc. 
$33,200
Rodan Builders, Inc. 
$68,500
	 
A notice of Intent to Award was sent to all bidders on June 17, 2014 and on June 21, 2014, Purchasing Services staff received a bid protest letter from the second apparent low bidder, Dexal Construction Inc. (Dexal).  The letter alleges that Nor-Cal Pipeline Services is not the lowest responsible bidder, since it had not included a signed Project Stabilization Agreement (PSA) in its bid and that Dexal “fulfilled correctly” the required submittals, therefore Dexal is the lowest responsible bidder. Purchasing Services consulted with District's legal counsel, Mr. Phillip Jaret, regarding the bid protest. It is Mr. Jaret's opinion that the failure of Nor-Cal Pipeline Services to include the requisite signed PSA documents with its bid, but a later curing of that shortly thereafter by Nor-Cal Pipeline Services with the executed documents, is a minor irregularity that can and should be waived by the District. 
	 
Nor-Cal Pipeline Services has successfully completed projects for East Palo Alto Sanitary District, City of Ione and City of Santa Cruz and signed the Appendix A, “Agreement To Be Bound,” and Appendix C, Construction Careers Program Agreement of Contractors, of the Project Stabilization/Construction Careers Agreement between the District and the Santa Clara & San Benito Counties Building and Construction Trades Council. 
	 
The bid price of $32,500 submitted by Nor-Cal Pipeline Services is within the construction estimate of $60,000 and it is within the overall project budget of $80,000.  This project is funded by Measure C.

Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services

Background and Analysis:
	 
District staff prepared proposals to provide on-going routine and regular annual service to abrade and recoat five gymnasium floors including an allowance for minor gameline repairs and painting at Foothill (2500, 2600) and De Anza (PE14, PE15, PE21) colleges.  The work shall occur in the Summer months, prior to start of Fall Quarter.  The bid specifications also required unit pricing for miscellaneous repairs to allow the District to call on the contractor throughout the remainder of the fiscal year for ongoing minor repairs and repainting as needed at the pre-established rates. 
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on May 7 and May 14, 2014. The “Invitation to Bid” was also posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on June 12, 2014 in the Purchasing Services office. Three (3) contractors submitted bids and the results are below:
BID RESULTS
Contractor
Base Bid 
Proposal Amount – 
Year 1
Merit Floor Care
$ 29,340
HY Floor and Gameline Painting, Inc.

The lowest responsive and responsible bidder is Merit Floor Care.  Merit has successfully performed gymnasium refinishing and floor maintenance for other public entities such as Diablo Valley College and City of Palo Alto. 
Therefore, it is the Districts’ intent to enter into a one-year agreement with Merit for annual maintenance of the gymnasium floors (including the option to contract annually for up to four (4) additional one-year terms).  The pricing submitted by Merit is firm for Year 1 services and shall not increase for Year 2 services unless the District adds or deletes scope. Adjustments in prices may commence beginning the third year not to exceed 3 % per year. It is anticipated that over the course of five years that the aggregate cost of the annual maintenance would be approximately $160,000.  Minor repairs and repainting required throughout each year on an as needed basis will be by separate contract. The annual maintenance of the gymnasium floors will be paid for from Measure C Scheduled Maintenance funds.
